title: Are modern swords higher quality than medieval swords? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes if they're made in the right way. Today's steel is much more pure than steel made in the middle ages or even in the Renaissance. That means that we have less silicon and other impurities within the blade. Our options for the different types of steel have also increased. That being said a lot depends on who made the weapon. If the past forgers had constructed it right they would be able to make a blade Superior to a sword made now if the sword maker today did not use the right techniques. But know if you ever see cutting competitions where swords are used today by professionals and the swords are very high quality they would be able to use them to greater effect than swords made during the middle ages in Europe, Japan an or any other part of the world. The key is impurity in the smelting process however skilled the sword maker was in the middle ages she could not get past the fact that the smelted material was far less pure. The thing is that they weren't to be able to achieve the temperatures to get rid of all of those impurities found in sand and iron ore. That temperature is about 3,000 degrees. You also have to understand that the in technology in steel munufacturing today is downright amazing. I looked at a steel manufacters rundown of everything they can do with steel and they said that that they can make more than 10000 types of steel now for all different purposes. Many of those metals include alloys or the introduction of different metals within the steel so that they can be used for different purposes. Each of them has a different hardness and specific use. Forgers of the middle ages would be very very limited in the types of steel that they could use. You would have rusting and different issues with maintenance as well as more sharpening required for each blade. Chipping and durability would be a problem. You will see in blade forging for modern steel that most forgers use oil to quench their blades. Back then it was almost always required that they use water to get the utmost hardness for each sword and water provide the greatest potential hardnest. Today most blades are quenced oil. That's b ecause modern steel don't need the hardness that comes from the quenching in water in fact the process of quenching in water can cause the blade to crack and be destroyed in modern steel blade making. So the answer is yes.

I would say in some regards almost always, in others, no, generally not. If we look at steel quality, medieval swords are almost always only regular carbon steels, BETTER manufacturers nowadays use Cr, CrV or Ni steels, all of which have the potential to make for a much better quality sword in material. Yes, even better than the famed “Damascus steel swords”, it’s just a UHCS jacket around an iron core, nothing special about it if you understand basic metallurgy, in fact I’d rate “Damascus steel swords” worse than the average high-late medieval sword, in fact. Ibn Hodeil notes in the 1300s, "the fabrication of Frankish swords is the work of Genies." also noting how the “work of the Hindus (damascus steel swords) often shatters in cold weather (we are talking modern day Iran, so 15 °C and below)” Not to talk about historical steel being wrought iron most of the time, which is high in slag, which can lead to earlier material failure, while with modern steels this is less of a concern. Historically speaking a lot of swords also couldn’t afford to be the same kind of steel all throughout, so we have plenty of examples of a wrought iron core wrapped around with a high carbon steel jacket (yes this is the same as how katana are made nowadays and this is how most Japanese swords were made, albeit the highest quality versions of them were made out from a “single billet”). But still in some swords of Medieval origin you still don’t find slag with regular micrography.  No visible slag in either. What is a production but still material quality is heat treatment. Our ancestors didn’t have the luxury to use thermometers and they are crucial for proper heat treatment. So they had to rely on the color created by the temperature of the material. Fortunately for us, things start glowing at specific temperatures.  So when people saw a specific color they knew when to quench the sword. Where in general modern swords fall short however is the handling department. Unless you are buying swords on the high end like Albion, A&A, Landsknecht Emporium etc. you will, generally speaking, get a worse product for handling than even a lot of very cheap medieval swords. And handling in general is dependent on the form of the blade, even minor qualities (as far as looks concerned), like spine thickness, distal taper, fuller width, fuller length, blade cross section, guard weight etc etc WILL impact on the handling. There are also modern manufacturers that wouldn’t get much praise back then, like Cold Steel, Windlass Steelcrafts, Universal Swords, Nielo Swords, Depeka, Hanwei (they are on the better scale of the not so well handling ones, but their heat treatment has led to many breakages), etc. So all in all, modern swords are better in some regards, in others not so much. Unfortunately for modern manufacturers good enough material is #1 priority (which medieval swords are), handling is #2 priority and only after that there is a need for even better materials, as #1 will determine if it can serve at all or not, #2 determines how it serves both short and long term and #3 is how long it will serve. Let us break this down. Because it's an easy question to answer, with a twist. Certainly, many swords made today, in fact, a majority of them, may not meet - for lack of a better word - the quality of medieval swords. But not because of anything that has to do with our ability to make better swords. It has everything to do with why they are made - to be decoration rather than tools of war. To be imitations of the real thing. The knock-off souvenier katana. The mass-produced cavalry saber that folks swear is an heirloom. Most of the fancy fantasy swords that fetch a high price to today's fantasy collector. Now, if there was a need to make a combat-viable sword the answer is definitely yes. First, none of the techniques of making older swords has truly been lost. Finding someone who knows them may be a little harder - but if there was a need, the knowledge is there to be restored. And even so … Materials wise our metals are better, our metallurgy is better, and our ability to make and craft alloys is better, and our knowledge of material properties and how to craft them for a particular is better. Wootz steel is an interesting case, where access to a particular metal was lost. But it’s been found again. On the other hand … even when wootz steel vanished from the medieval toolbox, it did not stop the manufacture or quality weapons that were very battlefield capable. If there was a need, we are perfectly capable of creating swords to match or exceed the qualities of a medieval sword. But we don’t need to. We have created much easier and more effective ways of killing each other. The truth of the matter, alas, is that tragic truth.

Yes and no. The basic qualities used in the manufacturing process are more advanced. The knowledge and the use of higher quality more homogeneous steels ensure a better end product. The heat is better controlled today as well, we can control it via digital thermostats, the heat can be controlled by single degrees even. As well as the quality of the air and fuel used, preventing any imperfections being built into the sword. Naturally there are always going to be mistakes made and there are people who can make swords of great quality and are masters of the craft, just like the expert blacksmiths and specific sword making manufacturers of the past. And within those groups both ancient and today there are people who maybe mediocre and just plain poor quality swords as well. If they use poor materials, poor heat and poor quality air all can easily cause manufacturing defects today just as easily as in the past. High quality swords require, the best steels and raw materials, the best air quality within the forge and the control of the heat used to melt and forge the materials to make the sword.

The average modern sword (actual combat or combat ready sword, not cheap production for wall hanging, zombie killer posing, or backyard watermelon chopping) is of much higher quality than the average Medieval sword. However, there were exceptionally high quality swords made during Medieval times can rival the better swords of today. The biggest problem back then was the quality of the steel. It was very difficult to control the quality of the bloom. Much of the techniques went in to compensating for the often inconsistent quality of the billets. Today, we have much better steel production control as well as quality control in the sword making itself. Our understanding of metallurgy is such that we can control the additives to achieve greater hardens, toughness and strength. It should be noted that surviving Medieval swords are not representative of the swords back then. It is usually the best of the best that has survive to today.

Sort of yes, sort of no. We have better steel now and better tools with which to work that steel. so if nothing else, a medieval style sword made today should be objectively better, eventhough in actual practical use the difference likely won't be extremely noticable. In terms of design evolution not much had happened since the late 1800s. And its not that the late 1800s sword designs were necessarily 'better' than the medieval ones, they were just better for the specific purpose of battlefields or duels in the 1800s, which was quite different than battlefields in the middle ages. So different, yes, better, depends. When talking about 'modern' swords we also have to take into account that there is a far larger percentage of swords being produced for hanging on a wall as decoration than for use in fighting. So probably 'on average' modern swords are significantly worse for combat than they were in the middle ages, eventhough a high quality modern battleforged sword would be better than one from the middle ages.

I have destroyed many. A real knight had only on knife in his life.

If it’s a sword manufacturer like Wilkinson for people who use swords, then modern swords compare to medieval ones in the same way modern aircraft compare to medieval ones. My father’s infantry pattern sword had a mark on the blade near the hilt called the proof mark. The sword had actually been clamped in a vice, bent round until the tip touched the proof mark, and then let go. If it wasn’t straight afterwards it would have been on the reject pile. What we can do now is just beyond belief. It would seem like sorcery to a medieval smith. I am guessing that this is one of the reasons the Japanese have clamped down on manufacture. If it’s not “traditional” then it’s not permitted, otherwise we would have a hundred million Chinese made katanas that were considerable better than most of the traditional ones. Don’t knock the Chinese - if you get the spec right, they make it. It’s only when you say “make it cheap” that you get what you asked for.

In terms of average quality for most swords made, i’d say yeah. As for detailed construction and detail to fit and finish, i’d say no. Back when they were seriously used, they designed the swords against the most common issues of breakage in battle. This included softer metal in the tangs to prevent hilt breakage, tear drop style sharpening so the sharpened edge lasts longer, and more tightly fitting the hilt components to the sword to prevent the sword from eventually wobbling. The sheer majority of modern sword makers just don’t take all this into account. As for the steel quality used today, i’d say we’re far better now because we have much more consistent filtering and screening of steels as well as a much broader variety of suitable steels to choose from. Plus we’re able to manufacture said swords much faster than ever now.

Short answer steel is far more consistant and of better quality now but is generally not made for purpose i.e edge tempering. In design modern swords generally fall short (unless you go for a high end sword as mentioned in previous posts) Modern weaknesses in design include No distel taper Fullers going beyond the quillens The pommel not peened Wrong type of steel used Balancing point wrong for the type of sword Edge shape not optinmised for cutting i.e. flat blade with just the very edge sharpened

The sword manufacture town of solonge Germany was a board out husk. Sword manufacturing and sword smiths are still trying to rediscover this as lost knowledge. Even the best modren made swords fall short in ballance, temper, flexibility, and strength. And as a side note the stuff you buy at a shoping mall are all crap.

To summarize other’s who have answered this question correctly and in detail: Modern swords are almost always better and of higher quality than historical swords. However, if you don’t get from people who know how to properly make a sword they will have trash handling and feel 3 times heavier than they are and all of the fancy steels in them won’t rectify that. If you get a $500+ sword from Albion, A&A, Landsknecht you will almost certainly have something superior that any historic sword.

It depends are you asking about possible sword quality or overall quality. Now, if you are asking for possible quality I’d agree with everyone who is going on about the quality of modern steel but overall quality- I’d go with medieval swords. The reason is that most medieval swords had to be functional weapons while most modern are decorations and as such aren’t expected to hold up. There are quite a few swords on the market which some collectors would call wall hangers and sword type objects as they are simply not practical, due to low quality, bad design or both. Though as I stated earlier if you exclude the sword type objects and just focused on practical swords the modern ones win.

It depends on the person who makes the sword. There are modern day forgers and blacksmiths who make swords that are just as strong or stronger than medieval swords. If your referring to swords you see advertised on eBay and other sites for $35 to $75 then no. Those are commonly referred to as wall hangers and are usually pressed or stamped “pot metal” which is a mix of several materials to make the production cost cheaper. The most important part of a sword quality wise is the tang. Cheap swords have what is called a rat tail tang which is a threaded metal rod spot wielded onto the blade. A full tang sword is where the blade is all one solid piece of steel that is hammered out to be thinner on the end for the tang without compromising the quality of the sword.

The short answer, yes. The long answer, yeeeeeeeeeeeeeees. The answer with an explanation, well modern technology has the capability of removing far more impurities in metal than were capable of medieval forges. Have you ever heard of the original legend of Damascus steel? How it was able to literally cleave other swords in half? The reason for that was because the technique used on historical Damascus steel removed far more impurities than other countries/areas.

YES, we can make better swords, than they usually had, in medieval times, NO, generally, people do not go through the trouble, and expense, to do so. So a well made medieval sword, of high quality, is generally better than a “modern” sword, generally because “modern” swords are either ceremonial, or decorative, and not meant to be used in the archaic practice of pre-firearms sword melee’ style warfare.

That;s actually a hard question to answer. In most ways the metal is better way now than before. A lot of the metal making process during old times was done visually and through experience. When the metal turned a certain color then it was time for the next step and so forth. But when you factor in that sword makers then were experienced at their product being used they made better handling and in some instances better lasting swords, even from an inferior metal. They better understood where battle stresses were typically impacting and how the sword should handle. Handling in battle is important for a sword.

Yes/No. Modern steel is far better quality than anything that could be produced in medieval times. The only factually accurate answer is “It depends on a case by case basis.” Medieval blacksmiths would’ve probably killed for some modern steel alloys, and likely been at least wanting to try to make stuff with other materials just to see how it’d turn out. On the other hand, they’d probably be genuinely horrified by both the handling of, and and design of many modern swords.

As a general rule, they are made with BETTER steel, by folks that probably don’t have quite as much experience but close. Overall I’d say they average QUITE A BIT BETTER, but the best medieval swords can probably argue against better but not top-of-the-line modern “live steel”, they lose due to inferior metallurgy but not on skill of creation.

Yes and no. The metals today are higher quality and if made correctly would last longer and hold an edge longer than comparable styles of medieval swords However, there are some techniques used by swordsmiths when a persons life depended on the sword that are superior to the techniques used by most modern swordsmiths.

That would depend on who made the sword. Arms & Armor, Hanwei, most Cold Steel, and Lord of Battles produce swords that are consistently better than many medieval swords. Swords produced in India & Pakistan are very much inferior to most medieval swords.

I only know about Japanese swords and though the golden era of Japanese sword-making was the Kamakura period (1185–1333)), extremely good swords are still being made in the traditional manner today by Kaji (Japanese sword-maker). Some of these, such as the Gassan school, are rooted in the Kamakura period and have been making swords continuously, apart from when sword-production was banned under the occupation of Japan after the horrors of 1945. From memory, sword production was permitted to continue in 1947. The Japanese sword is considered to be the Japanese highest art-form by the Japanese, not merely a weapon. It takes a great deal of study, viewing of many fine swords and knowledge of what to look for to understand this.

One might think the answer would be of course a modern sword is of higher quality than a medieval one, but there’s more to building a sword than just using modern steel the art of blacksmithing is nearly dead and thousands of years sword making secrets have been lost to history.
